summary: This is an FBI Public Affairs News Briefing from November 16, 2020, covering a wide range of national and international news. It includes a significant revelation about the Epstein case: a DOJ report found the FBI wanted to arrest Jeffrey Epstein at a Virgin Islands beauty pageant in May 2007, but the plan was halted by the U.S. Attorney's Office led by Alexander Acosta. The report also concluded Epstein was not assisting the government with the Bear Stearns case or acting as an intelligence asset.

events.title: FBI Plan to Arrest Epstein at Virgin Islands Pageant
events.description: The FBI planned to arrest Jeffrey Epstein during a beauty pageant in the Virgin Islands where he was a judge. The plan was halted after the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida, led by Alexander Acosta, frowned on it.

events.title: Epstein's Plea Deal and Surrender
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein surrendered to authorities after signing a plea deal.

keyFacts: A DOJ Office of Professional Responsibility report found the FBI had planned to arrest Jeffrey Epstein in the Virgin Islands in May 2007, but the plan was halted by the U.S. Attorney's Office.
The same DOJ report concluded that Epstein was not assisting the federal government in prosecuting Bear Stearns traders or serving as an 'intelligence asset,' contradicting long-standing rumors.
The report found that former Labor Secretary Alex Acosta exercised 'poor judgment' in overseeing the 2008 Epstein case but did not engage in professional misconduct.
The news briefing is a broad daily digest covering politics, protests, criminal investigations, and international news from November 2020, with the Epstein item listed under 'OTHER FBI NEWS.'
The document reveals a previously unreported detail about the FBI's specific plan to arrest Epstein at a beauty pageant.
